name.translation[0].definitions[0].examp: He married a young lady by the name of Sarah Hunt.
HH Munro wrote under the name Saki.
name.translation[0].definitions[1].defin: what a thing, organization, or place is called
name.translation[0].definitions[1].examp: The flower’s common name (=name that is used by ordinary people, not its scientific name) is forget-me-not.
What’s the name of the street?
The name of the company has changed.
Edo was the ancient name for Tokyo.
name.translation[0].definitions[2].defin: the opinion that people have about a person or organization
clear your name (=prove that you did not do something bad or illegal)
name.translation[0].definitions[2].examp: He didn’t want to do anything to damage the good name of the company.
The restaurant got a bad name for slow service.
They give the rest of the fans a bad name.
The company has a name for reliability.
He quickly made a name for himself in the Parisian art world.
make your name/make a name for yourself
name.translation[0].definitions[3].defin: a person, company, or product that is very famous or is known by many people
name.translation[0].definitions[3].examp: some of the biggest names in show business
It made the company into a household name  (=a very well-known person or thing).
name.translation[0].note_box[0].heading: – Meaning 1: what someone is called
name.translation[0].note_box[0].sections: have a name
All their children have French names.
give somebody a name
They gave their children unusual names.
use a name
She may be using a false name.
take a name
Are you going to take your husband’s name when you get married?
change your name
Many immigrants changed their names to seem more American.
give (somebody) your name
I gave my name to the receptionist.
know somebody’s name
His first name is Tom, but I don’t know his last name.
use somebody’s name
I didn’t know him well enough to use his first name.
call somebody’s name
He called Jean’s name, but there was no answer.
sign your name
Sign your name here, please.
call somebody by their first/full etc name
Everyone called him by his first name.
go by the name of ...
As he had long red hair, he went by the name of Red.
know somebody by name
The headteacher knew all the children by name.
greet somebody by name
The waiter greeted him by name.
name.translation[0].note_box[1].heading: – Meaning 3: the opinion that people have about a person or organization
name.translation[0].note_box[1].sections: The company wants to maintain its good name.
Most students feel that both boys and girls deserve a bad name if they sleep around.
They have a name for good quality food.
He made a name for himself as a conductor of the Berlin Orchestra.
She was determined to clear her name.
A scandal like this could give the university a bad name.
name.translation[0].note_box[2].sections: first name
the name chosen for you by your parents
People usually call each other by their first name.
Please write your given name and your date of birth.
Christian name
first name
His Christian name was Joseph.
last name/family name/surname
the name that you share with your family or husband. Most English speakers would say last name. Surname sounds slightly formal
Can I have your last name?
Johnson is a common English family name.
At school they used to call each other by their surnames.
middle name
the name between your first and last names
Harry Potter’s middle name is James.
full name
your first name, middle name, and last name
I need your full name and address.
maiden name
a woman’s family name before she married and began using her husband’s name
My mother’s maiden name was Higgins.
married name
a woman’s family name after she gets married, if she uses her husband’s name
I don’t know what her married name is.
nickname
a name that people call you because of your appearance, personality etc, which is not your real name
At school he was given the nickname ‘Shorty’.
stage name
the name that an actor uses which is not their real name
She began acting in her childhood under the stage name Marjorie Moore.
pen name
a name that a writer uses which is not their real name
Mark Twain was his pen name. His real name was Samuel Clemens.
She wrote under the pseudonym of George Eliot.
under an assumed name
using a false name in order to hide your real name
He had rented the car under an assumed name.
alias
a false name, especially one used by a criminal
He uses a number of aliases.
appellation
a name which describes something – a very formal use
This fine city justifies its appellation ‘the Pearl of the Orient’.
sobriquet
a nickname – a very formal use
Jackson gained the sobriquet ‘Stonewall’ at the Battle of Bull Run.
name.translation[1].definitions[0].defin: to give someone or something a particular name
name.translation[1].definitions[0].examp: He was named after his father.
The street is named after the famous South African leader, Nelson Mandela.
The college is named for George Washington.
name.translation[1].definitions[0].note_: In everyday English, people usually say someone or something is called something rather than named something:
He had a friend called Mick.
name.translation[1].definitions[1].defin: to say what the name of someone or something is, especially officially
name and shame British English (=say publicly who is responsible for something illegal that has happened, or who has not achieved a particular standard)
name.translation[1].definitions[1].examp: The two murder victims have yet to be named.
She has secret information and is threatening to name names (=name the people who were involved in something, especially something bad or illegal).
They’re a lot better than some airlines I could name.
The woman who was shot has been named as Mary Radcliff.
name.translation[1].definitions[2].defin: to officially choose someone or something, especially for an important job or prize
name.translation[1].definitions[2].examp: The film was named best foreign film.
Quinn has been named as the new team manager.
Fitzgerald was named to the committee by the chairman.
name.translation[2].definitions[0].defin: a member of Lloyd’s, the international group of insurance underwriters based in London. The Names are wealthy people who accept a financial risk in an insurance contract, and in return for this they usually make large profits. Sometimes they can lose a lot of money when events happen which affect insurance companies, such as serious accidents involving ships or planes, or severe weather conditions that cause a lot of damage.
